item.title: An Example of Using RabbitMQ From Go
item.description: Sending We’ll call our message publisher (sender) send.go and our message consumer (receiver) receive.go. The publisher will connect to RabbitMQ, send a single message, then exit. package main import ( "log" "github.com/streadway/amqp" ) func failOnError(err error, msg string) { if err != nil { log.Fatalf("%s: %s", msg, err) } } func main() { conn, err := amqp.Dial("amqp://guest:guest@localhost:5672/") failOnError(err, "Failed to connect to RabbitMQ") defer conn.Close() ch, err := conn.Channel() failOnError(err, "Failed to open a channel") defer ch.

item.title: An Example of Using Nsq From Go
item.description: NSQ is a message queue, similar to RabbitMQ. I decided Iâ€™d give it a whirl. Install Nsq brew install nsq Launch Nsq nsqlookupd & nsqd --lookupd-tcp-address=127.0.0.1:4160 & nsqadmin --lookupd-http-address=127.0.0.1:4161 & Get Go client library go get github.com/nsqio/go-nsq Create a producer package main import ( "log" "github.com/bitly/go-nsq" ) func main() { config := nsq.NewConfig() w, _ := nsq.NewProducer("127.0.0.1:4150", config) err := w.Publish("write_test", []byte("test")) if err != nil { log.
